title: What Vance saw in Iraq
description: The vice president’s four years in the Marine Corps planted the seeds of his populism — and his pursuit of power.
content:
Vice President JD Vance once described himself as “a young idealist” when he deployed to Iraq as a Marine in 2005. But when he came back, he was different. “I returned in 2006, skeptical of the war and the ideology that underpinned it,” he wrote in The Lamp, a Catholic literary journal, in 2020.

Just months after writing that, he leaped into the Ohio Senate race that ultimately set him on the path to the vice presidency.

Vance hasn’t discussed his time in the military all that much since then. But what he saw in Iraq, back when he was still known as Cpl. James D. Hamel, left an indelible impression on Vance as a person — and on his politics.

“In the Marine Corps, Vance began to form many of the ideas and inclinations that have come to define his broader political philosophy,” writes Ian Ward in this week’s Friday Read: “his skepticism of political elites, his antagonism toward the news media, his ambivalent view of liberal democracy and even his restrictive ideas about immigration and American citizenship.”

Ward’s in-depth piece on how the military shaped Vance kicks off POLITICO Magazine’s new War Issue. Over the course of next week, the magazine will publish an ambitious collection of deeply reported stories investigating the turbulent present and uncertain future of U.S. military dominance — and of warfare itself. You can read them on POLITICO, and you’ll find all of them in next week’s special edition of POLITICO Weekend.

Until then, we look back at the long shadow of Vance’s four years in the Marines, “one of the most formative periods in his young-adult life.”

“I want to try and get to heaven, if possible. I’m hearing I’m not doing well. I am really at the bottom of the totem pole.”

Can you guess who dissed ... themselves? Scroll to the bottom for the answer.**



Where Are the Mass Protests? ... Hundreds of thousands of people took to the streets of Washington in the summer of 2020 to protest the police killing of George Floyd and racial discrimination. But President Donald Trump’s recent federal takeover of local law enforcement hasn’t prompted anywhere near that level of protest. “Local elected officials, eager not to provoke the administration, have been diplomatic in expressing their dismay,” writes Capital City columnist Michael Schaffer. “Notably, the small protests I went to were dominated by dedicated activists. ... By contrast, there was little evidence of, you know, the Democratic Party.”



The FBI raided who? If you somehow missed the news about the bureau searching the home and office of former national security adviser John Bolton, not to worry. Just go undercover and drop these details into conversation at happy hour. No one will suspect a thing. (From Associate Editor Dylon Jones)

— Hint at your familiarity with FBI and legal procedure with an insight into the paperwork: “They couldn’t have gotten a search warrant without convincing a judge there was something they might find there. Could mean their investigation is pretty far along.”

— Challenge your friends to see who can name the most people who’ve crossed Trump only to find themselves under some kind of federal probe or investigation. You can win if you memorize a bunch of them — just try to make it look natural, like you have to search for a couple: former FBI director James Comey, New York Attorney General Letitia James, Democratic Sen. Adam Schiff of California, former CIA director John Brennan, former homeland security official Miles Taylor, and Democratic Virginia Rep. Eugene Vindman, whose twin brother — retired Army Lt. Col. Alexander Vindman — was a witness in Trump’s first impeachment.

— Share this analysis from Guardian reporter (and former POLITICO fellow) Joseph Gedeon to show off how much you know about the key players: “Five of the people we just named were in FBI director Kash Patel’s book, Government Gangsters: The Deep State, the Truth, and the Battle for Our Democracy, back in 2023. Remember this came up in his confirmation hearings? There was an appendix that had a list of 60 names in it. Patel denied that it was an enemies list, but five have been investigated within seven months.”

— Everyone will mention Bolton’s memoir, The Room Where It Happened, and how the Justice Department failed to stop its publication with a lawsuit. But you’ll be the only one sharp enough to remember: “When they sued to try to prevent the book from publishing, they also went after Bolton’s $2 million advance. Guess we’ll see what it cost him. Even the judge who let the book go forward said that ‘Bolton likely jeopardized national security interests by disclosing classified information’ in violation of the NDA he signed when he joined Trump 1.0.”



What Really Happened to Austin Tice? ... In 2012, 31-year-old journalist Austin Tice went missing in Syria. “A rebel driver he knew was driving him from Darraya to Lebanon and safety,” writes James Harkin. “En route, he simply vanished.” For 13 years, the case befuddled multiple administrations, leaving his family without answers. But now, 13 years after Tice went missing, a “dramatic recent development” may have changed everything — and diminished the hope that he could still be alive.



A Veteran Diplomat’s Idea for Ukraine ... Trump has called for Ukraine and Russia to skip a ceasefire entirely and go straight for a peace agreement. But in a new interview, veteran diplomat Richard Haass — who has served under four presidents and negotiated over conflicts in Cyprus, the Middle East and Asia — tells Nahal Toosi that “it’s a big tactical error to rule out a ceasefire and go directly to final status [issues], because it’s most likely to prolong the war and make it difficult, if not impossible, to succeed.” He also said that despite what Trump may think, his personal relationship with Putin may not matter much at all.



Trump Wants China Out of Panama ... In his inaugural address, Trump reiterated his view that China controlled the Panama Canal, pledging to take it back. But he’s not stopping with the canal. Eight months later, Trump “has looked far beyond the canal for ways to undercut Chinese influence in Panama,” writes Jared Mitovich — “and created a political headache for leaders here.” That includes President José Raúl Mulino, who has faced national uproar over his perceived concessions to Trump.



From the drafting table of editorial cartoonist Matt Wuerker.



**Who Dissed? answer: It was Trump on Trump. He made the self-deprecating joke in a Fox & Friends interview about his attempt to negotiate a peace deal between Russia and Ukraine, saying that if he “can get to heaven, this will be one of the reasons.”

scraped_sources.text:
When Kash Patel, the FBI director, faced senators during his confirmation hearings on 30 January, he bristled at suggestions that his 2023 book contained an “enemies list”. The appendix to Government Gangsters, which included a list of names for around 60 people, was simply documentation of those who had “weaponized” the government, he insisted.
Seven months later, that denial appears increasingly hollow. Friday’s FBI search of the former national security adviser John Bolton’s home and office, reportedly to find classified documents, marks the fifth investigation targeting people from Patel’s book.
Bolton now joins a growing list of Trump critics from Patel’s roll the administration has targeted with what appear to be retaliatory federal investigations: James Comey, the former FBI director, John Brennan, the former CIA director, Miles Taylor, the ex-homeland security official and Lt Col Alexander Vindman. All five people, investigated in just seven months, were on Patel’s 60-name list.
Typically, federal prosecutors open cases based on tips, evidence or ongoing criminal activity. They don’t work their way through the index of a political book. While there is no public evidence that the book itself or any outside group is directing investigations, the overlap appears more than coincidence. The Biden justice department definitively closed both civil and criminal proceedings against Bolton in 2021 over his memoir about his time in the Trump White House. Bringing that investigation back to life requires a deliberate decision to re-litigate an already settled matter.
Bolton’s investigation, like those into the other four on Patel’s list, is unprecedented in how it is calculated to target a critic. The justice department acknowledged opening criminal investigations into Comey and Brennan over their 2016-2017 Russia investigation roles. Taylor faced presidential orders revoking his security clearance and demanding investigations into his anonymous anti-Trump writings. The DC interim US attorney pressed representative Eugene Vindman for business records tied to Ukraine aid, targeting the twin brother of Alexander Vindman, who testified against Trump during his first impeachment.
When asked for details about the raids and the reasoning behind them, a spokesperson for the FBI did not answer directly.
“The FBI is conducting court authorized activity in the area,” the spokesperson said in a statement. “There is no threat to public safety. We have no further comment.”
The systematic nature of these investigations exposes the fundamental contradiction in the administration’s approach. Officials claim to be combating the “weaponization” of justice while at the same time weaponizing it against a pre-compiled list of critics.
Notably, Patel’s targets are both “deep state” bureaucrats and former Trump allies. Along with Joe Biden, Kamala Harris and Hillary Clinton, they include Trump’s own former officials like the former defense secretary Mark Esper and Stephanie Grisham, the press secretary, a suggestion that the list features anyone who crossed or flipped on the president, regardless of their previous loyalty. Patel on Friday morning posted on social media that “NO ONE is above the law”.
Trump’s reaction to the Bolton investigation undermines claims of prosecutorial independence. Asked about the raids, the president claimed ignorance while launching familiar attacks: Bolton was “sort of a lowlife” and “could be a very unpatriotic guy – we’re going to find out”, he told reporters on Friday.
By systematically investigating critics while claiming to restore justice department integrity, the administration is creating an environment in which political opposition becomes presumed as evidence of criminal behavior.
This marks another example of evolution from Trump’s first term, when efforts to weaponize federal law enforcement were often chaotic and ultimately unsuccessful. The current approach appears more disciplined, with Patel’s book providing targets and Bondi’s working group providing bureaucratic cover.

argos_summary: Vice President JD Vance’s four‑year Marine Corps tour in Iraq hardened his skepticism of elites, media, and liberal democracy, a theme explored in a POLITICO Magazine War Issue. The article also covers a range of political events, from the muted 2020 protests over George Floyd to a series of FBI raids on former Trump allies—including John Bolton—linked to a controversial book by former FBI director Kash Patel. It reports on the long‑mysterious disappearance of journalist Austin Tice, a diplomat’s warning against bypassing a ceasefire in Ukraine, and Trump’s push to remove Chinese influence from Panama. Finally, a tongue‑in‑cheek “Who Dissed?” segment reveals Trump jokingly self‑deprecating about a peace deal with Russia in a Fox & Friends interview.
